prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum observations - target set 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose for dust continuum observations with ALMA in Band 7 for brown dwarf discs in USco association, with an aim to obtain disc mass and size measurements and compare with theoretical model predictions on brown dwarf formation mechanisms. The high sensitivity afforded by ALMA is required, in order to detect the faintest of these disc sources, extending down to ~0.01 Msun targets.
Our total sample consists of 54 targets. We have divided them into two science goals, since all of the targets are not within 10 degree of each other.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will use the single continuum setup in Band 7 (343.5 GHz rest frequency). The bandwidth in each sideband in this setup is of 1875 MHz. The representative frequency is set to 350.5 GHz.

The predicted outer disc radii for our targets as estimated from RT modeling are in the range of ~40-200 AU. We therefore require a configuration that gives a maximum recoverable scale of at least 200 AU, or about 1.4arcsec at the distance of ~145 pc to USco. Our targets have a RA of ~15-16 hour. High frequency projects (band 7, 8, 9, 10) have a low chance to be observed around the winter months (December-February) and during the day time due to the poorer atmospheric stability and higher system temperatures (as explained in the ALMA Proposer's Guide). Therefore, skipping the winter months and day time observing, we have only two options left of C36-2 and C36-3 configurations, as can be seen in Table 3 of the Proposer's Guide, both of which provide similar resolution and maximum recoverable scale. We have chosen the C36-2 configuration, as the total time estimate is slightly lower (by ~5 minutes) compared to C36-3. The C36-2 configuration provides a maximum recoverable scale of ~7arcsec that corresponds to a projected spatial scale of ~1015 AU at the distance to USco. This is adequate to recover the full spatial scale predicted by RT model fits for our target discs. We note that the inner disc radii are estimated to be ~0.1-0.6 AU for these BD discs, and cannot be resolved even if we use the C36-7 configuration with ~0.04 arcsec resolution (~6 AU at 145 pc).
Figure 4 (in the scientific justification) shows a simulated image of a M7 BD disc target, created using the ALMA Observation Support Tool (OST). We have used the C36-2 configuration in Band 7. We have used the SCUBA-2 850mu observation as the input image. The output image shows that the flux from the point source is fully recovered in this configuration.
We will not require ACA configuration since none of the targets are expected to show any large extended emission.

We prefer to observe in Band 7 since continuum detection at a ~3-sigma level has previously been confirmed with JCMT/SCUBA-2 850mu observations for two of the M6-M7 BD disc targets. Our targets cover a range in spectral type between M6 to L2. We have conducted radiative transfer (RT) modeling of the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) for all of our targets in order to determine the required sensitivity and configuration. The predicted flux densities at ~870mu from the best model fits are in the range of ~1-18 mJy, and the disc outer radii are in the range of ~40-200 AU. We have therefore set the desired sensitivity to ~0.2 mJy, so that we can obtain at least a ~5-sigma detection for even the faintest of the BD discs in the sample. With deep imaging, we expect to detect the L dwarf discs with predicted 870mu flux density of ~1 mJy. We note that we cannot observe at the lower frequencies in Band 6, since the expected continuum fluxes at 1mm obtained from extrapolating the RT model fits for the targets are <0.1 mJy, and would require a much longer time to reach the desired sensitivity.
In the ALMA OT, we have set the desired sensitivity to 0.2 mJy, the angular resolution to 0.5arcsec (for C36-2 configuration), and used the aggregate bandwidth of 7.5 GHz to calculate the sensitivity. This gives a sensitivity of ~0.195 mJy, resulting in a continuum S/N of ~5 for the faintest targets. The total time, including calibration and overheads, required for this science goal is 1.48 hour.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum observations - target set 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We propose for dust continuum observations with ALMA in Band 7 for brown dwarf discs in USco association, with an aim to obtain disc mass and size measurements and compare with theoretical model predictions on brown dwarf formation mechanisms. The high sensitivity afforded by ALMA is required, in order to detect the faintest of these disc sources, extending down to ~0.01 Msun targets.
Our total sample consists of 54 targets. We have divided them into two science goals, since all of the targets are not within 10 degree of each other.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will use the single continuum setup in Band 7 (343.5 GHz rest frequency). The bandwidth in each sideband in this setup is of 1875 MHz. The representative frequency is set to 350.5 GHz.

The predicted outer disc radii for our targets as estimated from RT modeling are in the range of ~40-200 AU. High frequency projects (band 7, 8, 9, 10) have a low chance to be observed around the winter months (December-February) and during the day time due to the poorer atmospheric stability and higher system temperatures (as explained in the ALMA Proposer's Guide). Figure 4 (in the scientific justification) shows a simulated image of a M7 BD disc target, created using the ALMA Observation Support Tool (OST). We have used the C36-2 configuration in Band 7. We have used the SCUBA-2 850mu observation as the input image. The output image shows that the flux from the point source is fully recovered in this configuration.

We prefer to observe in Band 7 since continuum detection at a ~3-sigma level has previously been confirmed with JCMT/SCUBA-2 850mu observations for two of the M6-M7 BD disc targets. This gives a sensitivity of ~0.195 mJy, resulting in a continuum S/N of ~5 for the faintest targets. The total time, including calibration and overheads, required for this science goal is 40 minutes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It is unclear to what degree the environment shapes the outcome of the star-formation process. Brown dwarfs (BDs) and their discs provide us with a unique way to identify possible differences in star formation in dispersed associations and dense clusters. The aim of this proposal is to use disc observations as proxies to determine the dominant formation mechanism of the lowest mass objects in different environments. We will focus on the Upper Scorpius OB association (USco), which is the nearest and the most recent site of both high and low mass star-formation. There are notable anomalies observed in the disc properties for BDs in this dispersed association, suggesting a different formation mechanism than in dense clusters. We will utilize ALMAs unprecedented capability to observe discs around a complete sample of BDs in USco. In particular, the disc masses around BDs hide important information about their formation mechanism. These observations will also highlight the likelihood of planet formation around BD discs in dispersed associations. Our proposed study will be fundamental in understanding if associations and clusters are notably different modes of star formation.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Jeremiah Horrocks Institute, Central Lancashire, University of
